metadata.title: Stimuli-Responsive Self-Assembled DNA Nanomaterials for Biomedical Applications

sections.text:
© 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com (1 of 16) 1602881
DNA Nanomaterials
Stimuli-Responsive Self-Assembled DNA Nanomaterials for Biomedical Applications
Ziwen Dai, Hoi Man Leung, and Pik Kwan Lo*
Stimuli-responsive DNA-based materials represent a major class of remarkable functional nanomaterials for nano-biotechnological applications. In this review, recent progress in the development of stimuli-responsive systems based on self-assembled DNA nanostructures is introduced and classified. Representative examples are presented in terms of their design, working principles and mechanisms to trigger the response of the stimuliresponsive DNA system upon expose to a large variety of stimuli including pH, metal ions, oligonucleotides, small molecules, enzymes, heat, and light. Substantial in vitro studies have clearly revealed the advantages of the use of stimuli-responsive DNA nanomaterials in different biomedical applications, particularly for biosensing, drug delivery, therapy and diagnostic purposes in addition to bio-computing. Some of the challenges faced and suggestions for further development are also highlighted.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nanotechnology has had a significant impact on many disciplines of science including physics, biology, nanoelectronics, and materials science. Significant effort has been devoted to the development of nanomaterials in response to stimuli.[1] Researchers have developed different approaches to generate stimuli-responsive nanomaterials, which show the ability to respond in an autonomous manner upon being triggered by an external stimulus such as chemicals, heat, light, etc. Nanomaterials such as liposomes,[2] polymers,[3] solid nanoparticles,[4] micelles,[5] gold nanorods,[6] magnetic nanoparticles[7] have demonstrated their stimuli-triggered responses and showed their potentials in drug delivery, biosensing, diagnostics, and therapy. These responses generally include morphology switching, conformation expansion or contraction, assembly or aggregation, disassembly or degradation, and the induction of motion.
DNA is typically the central hereditary material for transmission and storage of genetic information in biological systems. The work of Seeman and his co-workers has revealed DNA as a versatile building block to construct complex nanoscale assemblies.[8]
The size and complexity of self-assembled DNA building blocks were further increased by introducing the basic design principles of DNA origami approach by Rothemund in 2006.[9] Compared with other materials, the most attractive feature of DNA is its programmable molecular recognition capability, making it a promising candidate for the creation of predictable DNA nanostructures at the molecular level. In addition, DNA can react with a wide variety of tool enzymes which provide a rich toolkit for the manipulation of DNA. Furthermore, self-assembled DNA nanostructures show excellent biocompatibility and high stability in cellular environment, facilitating their in vivo and in vitro applications. Finally, the base sequences of DNA encode substantial structural and functional information, facilitating the rational design of stimuli-triggered nanomaterials.
For example, cytosine (C)-rich oligonucleotides selfassemble under appropriate pH values into i-motif structures, and guanosine (G)-rich strands assemble into G-quadruplex structures in the presence of ions such as K+ or NH4
+. Hairpin structures can also be generated from self-complementarity. The key advantage of integrating these functional nucleic acids into self-assembled DNA structures is their reversible switching under proper conditions; i-motif structures are uncoiled to random strands at neutral pH while G-quadruplex structures dissociate by ligand-induced replacement. Hairpin strands open upon the addition of nucleic acids with the base sequences complementary to the loop regions. Sequence-specific nucleic acids (aptamers) have been easily integrated to programmable DNA nanostructures for biosensing or molecular detection due to their high affinity for certain proteins or catalytic properties.
In parallel, synthetic organic or inorganic molecules can be inserted to the DNA strands to control the spontaneous DNA assembly of diverse architectures. Since these synthetic molecules possess intrinsic functionalities such as photophysical, redox, magnetic, and catalytic properties, they
allow the rational design of the final structures with complex functions. Photoisomerization of the trans-azobenzene unit into cis-azobenzene unit or vice versa alter its intercalation affinity between duplex DNA, resulting in reversible disassembly and assembly of the well-designed, doubled-stranded nanostructures. Photocleavable molecules including 2-nitrophenyl and 4-nitro-4′-phenoxy-1,1′-biphenyl molecules can be activated by different wavelengths of lights and thus their chemical bonds are broken to regulate the conformation or motion of the self-assembled DNA nanostructures. In fact, no other materials can take all of the aforementioned advantages, making DNA an attractive, versatile, and easily manipulated scaffold for the construction of novel nanomaterials for potential applications in biology and medical applications. The probabilities to trigger structural switching of DNA nanomaterials by means of external stimuli confer a strong implement of tools to manipulate DNAs.
The focus of this review is to introduce and classify recent progress in the development of a stimuli-responsive system based on self-assembled DNA structures. Representative examples will be presented and detailed summaries of their design and mechanisms to trigger the response of the stimuliresponsive DNA system upon expose to a large variety of stimuli including pH, metal ions, oligonucleotides, small molecules, enzymes, heat, and light will be discussed. The most recent examples of biomedical applications of these systems will also be presented. This review article also highlights some of the challenges faced and suggestions for further development.

sections.heading: 2. Stimuli Responsive DNA Nanomaterials
sections.text: In the following section, we will briefly introduce the most recent examples of stimuli-responsive DNA nanomaterials in terms of the design and triggered mechanism.

sections.heading: 2.1. pH-Responsive Systems
sections.text:
pH gradients have been widely used in the design of stimuli-responsive nanosystems for biomedical applications. These DNA-based systems are typically based on assemblies that are capable of structural changes upon receiving a pH signal. Cytosine would be protonated to become C+, which either forms a C+G-C triplex with GC pair or forms an
small 2017, 1602881
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(3 of 16) 1602881© 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com
intramolecular/ intermolecular secondary structure called an i-motif. These structures could only be stabilized in slightly acidic conditions, while they would dissociate to random coil or double helix in neutral or slightly basic conditions. Mao’s group has developed a smart DNA tetrahedron that could only be assembled in slightly acidic conditions (Figure 1A).[10] They first assembled a symmetrical three-point-star motif that consisted of a cytosine-rich sequence in the sticky end. When in neutral or basic conditions, the sequences were in double helix form and they could not form a tetrahedron. When the pH of the system was changed to about 5, cytosine would be protonated and formed a C+G-C triplex, which would connect four units of the three-point-star motif into one tetrahedron. In this way, assembly and disassembly of tetrahedron would reversibly be manipulated by the switching of pH from 5 to 8 and vice versa. In Ricci’s group, they constructed a DNA nanoswitch employing the C+G-C triplex structure as the key sensing element and the nanoswitch could sense a narrow range of pH changes.[11] The DNA nanoswitch was constructed by intramolecular formation of C+G-C structures. Since the C+G-C structure could only be stabilized in slightly acidic conditions, the change of pH from acidic to basic would disintegrate the structure and revert the whole switch to a double helix with a tail of single stranded random coil. Importantly, the nanoswitch would respond to different pH ranges with varying T-AT contents and sense a pH range of up to 5 units. Similarly, Liang’s group also used the C+G-C triplex structure as the responsive component to drive the toehold-mediated strand displacement.[12]
In Willner’s group, they constructed an interconnected two-ring DNA structure bridged by the C+G-C triplex and TA-T triplex (Figure 1B).[13] When the system was in acidic conditions (pH 5), the C+G-C triplex would form and the two rings would be separated due to the detachment of the bridge sequences from the rings. When the pH of the system was changed to 10, the TA-T triplex dissociated into random coil states and the two rings also separated. Thus, the system would change between separated rings and interconnected rings accordingly when the pH values were changed.
I-motif structures were also widely used to construct the logic gates. Proton would be used as an input to trigger the i-motif formation.[17] The strands for forming the i-motif structures were functionalized with a fluorophore/quencher pair at the two ends and the formation of the i-motif structures would change the distance between the fluorophore and quencher. This leads to the quenching or restoring of fluorescence emission. While Liu’s group has also introduced the i-motif structure into the building blocks of DNA-based dendrimer to construct a size-tunable dendrimer (Figure 1C).[14] The i-motif structure was integrated into the building block of G1 layer of the dendrimer and the remaining layers were just composed of regular DNAs. Dendrimers were assembled in neutral conditions. When the pH of solutions was changed to acidic, the inner core of the dendrimer would collapse and the diameter of the dendrimer would decrease, which was well confirmed by the dynamic light scattering measurement. In addition, Famulok’s group incorporated the i-motif sequences into a DNA nanocircle (Figure 1D).[15] They studied two different types of i-motif sequences, in which one
Pik Kwan Lo received her BS and MPhil in Chemistry from Hong Kong Baptist University in 2004 and 2006. She obtained her PhD degree from McGill University in 2010 under the supervision of Professor Hanadi F. Sleiman. After that she moved to Harvard University for her postdoctoral research. In 2012, she joined City University of Hong Kong as an assistant professor. Currently, her research interests include design and assembly of bio-inspired DNA-based nanostructures and synthesis of advanced nanomaterials for biomedical applications.
Ziwen Dai received his BS degree in Chemistry from Nankai University in 2009. He joined Dr. Lo’s research group in 2013 as a full-time PhD candidate. His research interests focus on the assembly of stimuli-responsive DNA nanostructures as well as the construction of smart DNA nanostructures as platforms for detection and diagnosis.
would dominantly form intramolecular i-motif structure and the other would form intermolecular i-motif structures. By using different sequences of i-motif, contraction and extension of the nanocircle was attributed to the intramolecular i-motif sequences while dimerization of the nanocircle was attributed to the intermolecular i-motif sequences. More importantly, this is the first time of visualizing the i-motif folding pattern by atomic force microscopy (AFM) studies.
In Ren’s group, they constructed a DNA nanospring system that was sensitive to pH changes (Figure 1E).[16] The DNA nanorings were connected by a G-rich sequence that was able to form G-quadruplex structure. In the system, they also added an i-motif-forming strand. In neutral or basic conditions, the i-motif sequences would bind to the complementary G-quadruplex-forming sequences to form a rigid duplex. This would separate the two rings and the nanospring would take an “extended” state. While in the slightly acidic conditions, the i-motif sequences would form the i-motif structures and the G-quadruplex strand could be free from the duplex, resulting in the formation of G-quadruplex. The G-quadruplex brought the two rings closer so the nanospring would take a “compressed” state. More importantly, this protondriven DNA nanospring would not suffer from a permanent deformation.

sections.heading: 2.2. Metal Ions-Responsive Systems
sections.text:
Some DNA sequences have been found to interact specifically with certain metal ions, such as K+, Mg2+, Pb2+, Hg2+, Ag+. They interacted with those metal ions in different manners.
small 2017, 1602881
www.advancedsciencenews.com
reviews
1602881 (4 of 16) www.small-journal.com © 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
For instance, some G-rich sequences would be stabilized and form a tetra-stranded structure called G-quaduplex in the presence of ions. In Mergny’s group, they designed a G-quadruplex-based switch that was mediated by Cu2+ ion.[18] In this work, the G-quadruplex was stabilized by K+ ion and then intercalated by bisquinolinium 360A. The addition of a Cu2+ ion would force the 360A to adopt a linear conformation that would not bind to G-quadruplex. The removal of Cu2+ ion by EDTA would change the 360A back to V-shape and thus restore its ability to G-quadruplex binding. Moreover, Willner’s[19] and Yu’s group[20] also designed Q-quadruplex based DNA switches immobilized onto the gold electrode. In Willner’s study, they found that the simultaneous addition of K+ ion and hemin would facilitate the formation of a stable G-quadruplex based DNAzyme to catalyse the reduction of H2O2. Furthermore, Dong’s group designed a G-quadruplex based DNAzyme for the ultrasensitive colorimetric detection of K+ ion.[21] They used the AGRO100 aptamer sequence to form a stable G-quadruplex in the presence of K+ ion and further complexed with hemin to form a DNAzyme. This DNAzyme could catalyse the oxidation of ABTS by H2O2 and give out a colorimetric signal. Meanwhile, they found the thrombin-binding aptamer as well as the 21-mer human telomeric DNA also showed their abilities to form catalytic DNAzymes with hemin. They all could be used to construct a sensing platform for ultrasensitive detection of K+ ions. In Jiang’s group, they also constructed a biomimetic nanochannel system which was functionalized with G-quadruplex on the inner wall.[22] The nanochannel was constructed with (polyethylene terephthalate) (PET) while its inner surface was functionalized with the single-stranded G-quadruplex DNA strands. They found that this free, single-stranded DNA strand could form a stable G-quadruplex structure or rigid double-stranded DNA in the presence of K+ ions or its complementary DNA strand respectively (Figure 2A). The addition of different substrates basically can change the diameter of the inner wall accordingly. These changes were confirmed by the difference between the input and output of electric currents. Sugiyama’s group observed the dynamic formation of a G-quadruplex structure in real-time with fast scanning AFM.[28] They constructed a DNA origami frame. Its inner wall was functionalized with two double-stranded DNAs in parallel consisting of four G-tracts. The two free toehold G-strands would form an intermolecular G-quadruplex in the presence of K+ ions. This G-quadruplex structure would connect the two parallel DNA strands together and showed an ‘X’ Shape within the DNA origami tiles (Figure 2B), while the removal of K+ ions would disrupt the G-quadruplex and revert it to parallel double strands. The same group also demonstrated a similar observation within a DNA origami structure at the single-molecule level.[23] The strands contained two parts, including the G-quadruplex forming sequences and complementary C-rich sequences. Without the addition of K+ ions or decreasing the pH value of the system, the two sequences would form a duplex and the system would demonstrate an ‘X’ shape within the origami tile. When K+ ions were added, or the pH value of the system was decreased to about 5, the formation of G-quadruplex or i-motif would break the duplex. The individual strands would then be
small 2017, 1602881
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(5 of 16) 1602881© 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com
arranged in a parallel manner, confirmed by high resolution AMF studies.
Several groups have exploited the bridging of Hg2+ for T-T pair and Ag+ for C-C pair to either reversibly modulate the activity of DNA polymerase[29] or design a tunable DNA switch[30] and logic gates.[31] In Park’s work, the Taq DNA polymerase was firstly deactivated by aptamer binding. In the presence of Hg2+ and Ag+ ions, this TQ21D aptamer could be strongly stabilized by the bridging of T-T and C-C pairs and the activity of DNA polymerase could be restored. Subsequently, the aptamer would be free for enzyme binding after addition of cystenine in the system. This would resulting in deactivating the polymerase activity again.
In addition, Willner’s group explored the catalytic cleavage ability of a Pb2+-dependent DNAzyme to control the formation of dimer and trimer origami tiles.[24] The origami tiles were connected by a strand, which was the substrate of the Pb2+-dependent DNAzyme. When Pb2+ was added, the active conformation of DNAzymes could be successfully formed and then the linking substrates between the origami tiles were sequentially cleaved. This would lead to the separation of the dimer origami tiles (Figure 2D). For the trimer cleavage, both Pb2+-dependent DNAzymes and Histidine-dependent DNAzymes were used as the components to control the system at the same time. The trimer could only be dissociated into monomers when both DNAzymes were activated in the response of Pb2+ and histidine. They also designed and constructed a series of logic gates based on the activity of Mg2+-dependent DNAzyme.[25] In this work, the polymerase would synthesize the strand that could form the DNAzyme in the presence of Mg2+. The formed DNAzyme would then cleave the DNA substrate (Figure 2C). The cleavage of the DNA strand would separate the fluorophore from the quencher and give out the fluorescence emission as the signal. Therefore, AND gates were constructed using both Mg2+ and polymerase as inputs.
Shi’s group has constructed an Ag+ mediated DNA logic gate system to sense H2O2 by monitoring the Tb
3+ luminescence (Figure 2E).[26] In principle, the Tb3+ ions could give
out luminescence after binding to the G-rich single-stranded DNA strands. When Ag+ ions were added, the C-rich strands would form a C-Ag+-C complex and detach from the double strands, which would set the G-rich strands free for the complexation with Tb3+. Cysteine would bind tightly to Ag+ ions and its addition would revert the C-rich strand back to double-stranded DNA. The luminescence of Tb3+ would then be turned off after de-complexation. H2O2 would oxidize the cysteine into cystine, and this would allow the Ag+ to be free from the bound state. Thus, the two properties could be coupled together for the detection of H2O2.
More recently, Shionoya’s group has synthesized a bi pyridine-modified nucleotide and incorporated it into three DNA strands that could bind to their complementary strands to form three pieces of duplex DNAs. They found that these six DNA strands would rearrange by themselves in the presence of Ni2+ ions and then finally formed two three-way junction structures with the help of a metal-coordination strategy (Figure 2F).[27] The removal of Ni2+ by EDTA would revert the two three-way junction structures to their three respective double-stranded DNAs. This conformational switching of the DNA strands is highly reversible.
In general, those DNA structures that were mediated by metal ions could be used to detect the presence of the metal ions or to construct metal-ions triggered logic gates that were important in environmental monitoring and food safety.[32]

sections.heading: 2.3. Oligonucleotide-Responsive Systems
sections.text:
DNA nanotechnology utilized a reaction mechanism called toehold-mediated strand displacement to allow the DNA nano assemblies to reconfigure upon adding a new DNA strand. In this displacement reaction, the incoming DNA strand first hybridize to a single-stranded toehold region of a double-stranded nanostructure. One of the strands bound in the well-formed nanostructure would then be displaced through a migration process. The overall reaction resulted
small 2017, 1602881
www.advancedsciencenews.com
reviews
1602881 (6 of 16) www.small-journal.com © 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
in replacing one of the DNA strands in the nanostructure with another DNA strand.[33] In Sleiman’s group, they designed and assembled a series of discrete 3D DNA nanostructures, including triangular, cubic, pentameric, hexameric prisms, biprisms, and heteroprisms, which could be structurally switchable via strand displacement strategy.[34] Meanwhile, they used a set of cyclic DNA templates to generate a number of discrete DNA- gold nanoparticle assemblies.[35] Specifically, they demonstrated write/erase functions of these assemblies via a DNA strand displacement. In the presence of the added DNA strand, one of the gold nanoparticles was selectively removed from the triangular-shaped DNA template (erasing step) while another particle with corresponding DNA sequences could come in and hybridize to the empty site (writing step). More recently, Sleiman and her co-workers reported the design of 3D DNA nanotubes from 11 pieces of unmodified DNA strands.[36] They simply could reversibly regulate the nanotube from fully double-stranded to partially or fully single-stranded by adding a specific DNA strand (Figure 3A).
Strand displacement was further used to control the closing and opening of an assembled DNA box.[37] Kjems and Gothelf constructed a nanoscale DNA box. The closed box was covered by a lid at the sixth face while the lid was linked by two DNA strands from two different faces. Before adding the fuel strands, the box was tightly closed by the lid. When the fuel strand was added, it would hybridize to the closing DNA strands on the lid and set the lid free, so the box was then open and the molecular payloads inside the box would be released (Figure 3B). This process was monitored by the reversible changing of the FRET signal from Cy3 to Cy5. Turberfield’s group has demonstrated the conformation
control of a self-assembled DNA tetrahedron by strand displacement approach.[38] They designed a DNA tetrahedron that was assembled from only 4 DNA strands. The fourth strand contained a hairpin loop in the middle. When the DNA tetrahedron was assembled, it became in a contracted state (Figure 3C). When the fuel strand was added, it would fully bind to the whole strand including the hairpin region and make the hairpin to form rigid duplex. In this situation, the DNA tetrahedron would be in an ‘extended’ state. This process was fully reversible according to the FRET and gel monitoring.
DNA strand displacement was also used to control the structural changes of the DNA origami based nanostructures. In Liu and Yan’s group, they constructed a hollow structure with a subtractive assembly method.[39] They first assembled a fully double stranded origami structure. Fuel DNA strands were then added to displace the middle part of the structure, and leaving the rest part of the structure hollow but still stable (Figure 3D). They demonstrated that without the subtractive assembly method, they could not get the desired structure. In addition, they demonstrated the more complex switching of the assembled DNA origami based quasifractal patterns.[40] They first assembled a square-shaped framework with hollow cavity. Hybridization strands were then added to connect the free swinging strands to create smaller inner square framework. By adding the antifuel strands, the well-formed, smaller square framework would disintegrate (Figure 3E). This whole process was fully reversible and was proved by high resolution AFM. Subsequently, they also employed the strand displacement approach to construct a three-input majority logic gate.[42] Kjems’s[43] and Wang’s[44] groups also developed fuzzy and Boolean logic gate system using strand displacement strategy.
small 2017, 1602881
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(7 of 16) 1602881© 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com
Strand displacement was also used to regulate the protein binding affinity of some DNA aptamers. Liu’s group has constructed a tweezer-like DNA machine.[41] In Liu’s design, the arms of the two double crossovers were integrated with the two aptamers for the human thrombin and were connected by the Holliday junction. It has been proved that the simultaneous binding of the thrombin by two aptamers would result in a more tight binding. When the fuel strand was added, it would displace the strand that connected the two arms (Figure 3F). Thus, the actual distance between the two aptamers would exceed the optimal distance for the two aptamers to bind to the same thrombin. This distance dependent effect was proved by the reversible restoration and suppression of fluorescence resonance energy transfer and gel electrophoresis. The same group also assembled an enzyme cascade.[45] Using the same strategy, they constructed an enzyme cascade system which consisted of glucose oxidase and horseradish peroxidase. The two enzymes were coupled to the end of the two arms of the double crossover which were further connected by a Holliday junction to form a tweezer-like structure. The distance between the two enzymes were manipulated by the tweezer arms. The successive addition of the fuel and antifuel strands would reversibly zoom in or zoom out the distance between the two enzymes. This would directly affect the final product of the enzyme cascade. If they were close enough, the final product would be the oxidized ABTS, which was easily detected by UV–Vis absorbance. If they were far away from each other, the final product would be the intermediate H2O2. Using this strand displacement method, they could control the final product of the enzyme cascade reactions. Similarly, Willner’s group used this approach to construct a tweezer-like structure to finely control the positioning of gold nanoparticles.[46]
A DNA strand displacement approach was also used to capture and release target proteins. In Harrison’s group, they used strand displacement for enriching the target proteins.[47] In this work, an aptamer was integrated at the end of one strand, which would bind to the substrate strand coupled onto the solid surface. After the immersion and incubation, the target protein was captured tightly by the aptamer while the waste would be washed away. Finally, the fuel strand was added to release the target strand into the solution. This strand displacement method
provided a rapid capture and release operation of target protein. Mao’s group even captured a transient event of formation of C+G-C triplex using the strand displacement method.[48] The triplex was stable only in slightly acidic conditions as mentioned in the above discussions. However, it could also be in a semi-stable state in neutral conditions. In this design, a third strand that could form a triplex was added and will replace the strand that could not form a triplex. Though this was a kinetically favored process, it could be captured and proved using a strand displacement method.
Not only DNA strand could be used in strand displacement approach, but also miRNA could be used as the input displacement strand. Song and Fan designed a DNA origamibased logic gate which used two miRNAs as the stimuli.[49] The two miRNAs, miR-21 and miR-195 would displace the two blocking strands while setting the signal strand to be free. This free, end-functionalized signal strand would engage in another strand displacement reaction and bind to the target strand on the surface, giving out fluorescence or electrochemical signals. In this way, they constructed a ‘lab on DNA origami’ system, which could be used to develop DNA origami-based computing.
As a versatile and powerful method, strand displacement was also used to discriminate single nucleotide variant,[50] to regulate the transcription pathway,[51] to sense microRNA in vitro[52] and to detect tumor-related mRNA in living cells.[53]

sections.heading: 2.4. Small Molecules-Responsive Systems
sections.text:
In Fan’s group, they performed logic operations on a DNA tetrahedron structures using ATP, proton and Hg2+ ion as the inputs (Figure 4A).[54] The aptamer sequence for ATP binding was incorporated into one of the edges of DNA tetrahedron and the presence of ATP would facilitate the formation of the tertiary structure, which would bring the fluorophore and quencher in proximity and thus quenched the fluorescence emission. Notably, their DNA tetrahedron based logic gates could also be used to detect ATP and Hg2+ ion in vivo and in vitro. Yokobayashi’s group has also constructed ‘AND’ and ‘OR’ logic gates based on a dual aptamer system in the presence of adenosine and thrombin.[55]
small 2017, 1602881
www.advancedsciencenews.com
reviews
1602881 (8 of 16) www.small-journal.com © 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
Mao’s group has also employed ATP as stimulus to trigger the layer separation of the multi-layered DNA tetrahedron (Figure 4B).[56] In this work, they first assembled three discrete DNA tetrahedrons with different sizes from similar three-point-star motifs. In the design, the smaller DNA tetrahedron was captured by the larger tetrahedron via a duplex linker formed from the adjacent two tetrahedrons. The DNA linkers were designed to contain the ATP binding aptamer. When ATP was added, ATP binding aptamer would have a strong binding affinity to the ATP molecules such that it would unhybridize from the duplex linker, resulting in the dissociation of adjacent layers of DNA tetrahedron.
Willner and co-workers have used ATP as the stimulus to trigger the controlled release of molecular payloads from a DNA microcapsule.[57] Tetramethyl rhodamine-modified dextran (TMR-D) was entrapped in the CaCO3 microparticles by co-precipitation. The particles were then first coated with a layer of positively charged poly(allylamine hydrochloride) (PAH), followed by a layer of double stranded DNA through electrostatic attraction. Subsequently, five more layers of double-stranded DNA were coated to prevent the leakage of cargoes, and different layers of DNA were cross-linked by a ATP aptamer binding strand. When ATP was added, the aptamer DNA strand would bind to ATP and form a ligand-aptamer complex. This would disrupt the cross-linking between different DNA layers and cause the dissociation of microcapsules (Figure 4C). Thus, the molecular cargoes, such as TMR-D could be released in a controlled manner by the ATP trigger.
Krishnan and co-workers have recently constructed an icosahedron nanocapsule, which would open and release the encapsulated cargoes upon the addition of a small molecule.[58] The icosahedron nanocapsule was composed of two halves, the upper half was incorporated with 10 overhangs that contained the aptamer sequence for cyclic-di-GMP (cdGMP). The overhangs would also connect the lower half by strand hybridization in the absence of cdGMP. When cdGMP was added, the overhangs would fold back and bind to themselves to form the aptamer-cdGMP complex. This complexation would disrupt the connection between the upper half and the lower half, resulting in opening of the icosahedron nanocapsule (Figure 4D). As a result, the encapsulated cargoes would be released in a chemically-triggered manner.

sections.heading: 2.5. Enzyme-Responsive Systems
sections.text:
Enzymes play a key role in many biochemical processes. Some enzymes, especially those could cleave DNAs, were also important for protecting the hosts from being invaded by foreign DNAs. Compared with other stimuli, the enzymeresponsive system shows an elegant biocompatible means of both high selectivity and sensitivity for different biology applications. In the past years, considerable efforts have been made in the development of enzyme-responsive DNA nanosystems in terms of inducing structural/functional changes of preformed DNA nanostructures. Enzymes have been used
as the inputs for the construction of logic gates: Li’s group employed the rolling circle amplification to construct simple DNA logic gates by using endonuclease as the input.[59] This RCA reaction could only be initiated when the primer was set free from a hairpin structure by the endonuclease. The dye SGI could intercalate into the product of the RCA reaction and give out fluorescence emissions as the output. By using two different endonucleases they constructed twoinput and three-input logic gates.
Mayer’s group has also constructed multi-level logic gates using a split DNA aptamer.[60] The ATP binding aptamer was split into two parts. Only in the presence of ATP, the two parts could be linked together to generate an electrochemical signal from the tagged ferrocene to the gold electrode. The addition of ADA, adenosine deaminase, would hydrolyze ATP into inosine triphosphate, resulting in no ATP binding to the aptamer. The two parts of the aptamer were eventually dissociated, resulting in the disruption of current output. Therefore, they constructed INH, INH-AND, INH-AND-XOR logic gates by using the enzyme ADA as one input accordingly.
In Wang’s group, they constructed colorimetric logic gates based on the G-quadruplex based DNAzyme.[61] The G-quadruplex forming sequences were attached at the end of a hairpin structure, which could form the horseradish peroxidase like DNAzyme in the presence of hemin. The addition of hemin would facilitate the formation of active catalytic center and catalyze the oxidation of TMB by H2O2, while the addition of the complementary strand of the G-quadruplex forming sequence would promote the formation of the more stable duplex strands and inhibit the formation of catalytic center. By using these two inputs, they constructed the NOR, IMP, AND, OR, INH gates accordingly.

sections.heading: 2.6. Thermal-Responsive Systems
sections.text:
Double-stranded DNA could unwind and separate into single-stranded DNAs through the breaking of hydrogen bonding between nucleobases under specific temperatures. This temperature is called melting temperature (Tm). Tm depends on the length of the DNA strand and its nucleotide sequence such as CG contents. Thus, heat could be used to modulate the DNA assembly process.
Vallee-Belisle’s group recently engineered a series of DNA stem-loop based nanothermometers to precisely monitor the temperature changes over a narrow range.[62] Since the DNA duplex could be dissociated by heating, the DNA duplex was sensitive to heating naturally. In this work, by tuning the buffer ionic strength, number of the nucleobase and the GC contents at the end of the loop, a series of DNAbased nanothermometers which could sense the temperature over a range of 15 °C with the precision of 0.05 °C have been successfully constructed. Interestingly, by mixing different sets of the DNA stem-loop based assemblies in a solution phase, they would be able to form a thermometer that responded homogeneously up to 90 °C (Figure 5A). In addition, Tang’s group demonstrated the example of the temperature-triggered release of cargoes from nanocarriers.[63] In this design, DNA-functionalized mesoporous silica nanoparticles
small 2017, 1602881
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(9 of 16) 1602881© 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com
were chosen as the nanocarrier while the cargoes were loaded into the pores trapped by the surface-grafted duplex DNA strands. By optimizing the length of the grafted DNA strands, controlled release of cargoes at specific temperatures could be achieved successfully (Figure 5C). The very narrow melting temperature range of the system ensured that cargoes would not be released below the critical release temperature. More importantly, since one of the closing DNA strands was covalently coupled to the surfaces of the silica nanoparticles, the release of cargoes could be controlled reversibly.
Liu’s group also used heat as a stimulus to trigger the disassembly of the well-formed DNA hydrogel.[64] The pure DNA-based hydrogel was formed through the cross-linking of a Y-shaped scaffold with a linear double-stranded linker. They found that these hydrogels respond to heat change. At the transition temperature, switching between the gel and sol state of the DNA assemblies reversibly happened (Figure 5B). This system also responded to enzymes through the insertion of enzyme-recognized sequences into the linear linkers. In Knudsen’s group, they also employed temperature as the stimulus to change the configuration of a pre-formed DNA tetrahedron.[65] In the design, the tetrahedron had two hairpins at one of the vertices of the tetrahedron. At the beginning, these hairpin structures would dissociate at high temperature, resulting in the opening of a valve from one vertex. Meanwhile, the cargo horseradish peroxidase would passively enter the inner cavity of the tetrahedron. When temperature was dropped, the valve would close and then the horseradish peroxidase would be encapsulated inside the tetrahedron accordingly. When the temperature was elevated again, the entrapped cargoes could be released again from the opened cavity (Figure 5D). Thus, by introducing the hairpin structures at the vertex, the opening and closing of the pre-formed DNA tetrahedron could be controlled by temperature.

sections.heading: 2.7. Light
sections.text:
Among all the stimuli mentioned above, light is highly attractive, as it exhibits instantaneous manipulation and can remotely trigger the response of the system with extremely high temporal and spatial precision with an ON/OFF switching manner. No waste accumulated to hamper the performance of the systems or cause toxicity to hosts, because light is a clean source. Therefore, light has been widely used as an excellent external stimulus to trigger the changes of formed DNA nanostructures. As DNA itself was not responsive to light excitation, some photoresponsive molecules had to be introduced into the self-assembled DNA nanostructures to endow these nanostructures with the ability to respond to light. In addition, in light-triggered DNA-based systems, switching profiles can be regulated via the adjustment of a wide range of parameters such as wavelengths, light intensity, duration of exposure, etc.
The first type of photoresponsiveness came from organic molecules that would change their conformation reversibly when excited by light indifferent wavelengths. The most accessible molecules would be azobenzene. When it was excited by light of wavelengths between 300 nm and 400 nm, it would be stabilized in the cis-conformation. When it was excited by light of wavelength more than 400 nm, it would be stabilized in the trans-conformation, which could inter calate very well in the double-stranded DNA while the cis-form could not. It has been widely used to manipulate the association and dissociation of azobenzene-modified DNA strands such that the conformation of DNA nanostructures could be optimized.
In early 2008, Asunuma and co-workers designed a simple DNA tweezer in which the opening and closing of the two arms could be controlled by photoregulation.[66]
small 2017, 1602881
www.advancedsciencenews.com
reviews
1602881 (10 of 16) www.small-journal.com © 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
The two arms were two rigid duplexes and modified with a fluorophore and a quencher respectively. When the complementary strands to the two arms were added, the two arms would be brought together and caused the quenching of the fluorescence emission. The complementary strands were incorporated with azobenzene moieties and when UV irradiation was applied, the azobenzene would take a cis form and destabilize the formed double strands. The detachment of the complementary strands from the tweezer due to photo isomerization would result in the separation of the two arms from each other. Later, they also tried to introduce the azobenzene moiety into DNA strands to modulate the hybridization and dehybridization of a hairpin structure.[67] These works represented the early attempts in regulating DNA hybridization through the introduction of photo responsive moieties. Subsequently, Asanuma’s group also constructed a photoregulated DNA nanomachine for the RNA digestion.[68] The DNA nanomachine was based on a DNAzyme. At the two ends of the DNAzyme forming strand, two azobenzene-incorporated strands were coupled. When the azobenzene were in trans form, the two complementary strands would bind to each other and form a stable duplex that would suppress the activity of the DNAzyme for RNA cleavage because the catalytic loop was in a constrained incorrect conformation. When visible irradiation was applied to the system, the azobenzene took the non-planar cis form and the dissociation of the duplex would release the steric hindrance and expose the catalytic sites to the RNA substrate. This resulted in cleaving the RNA efficiently. In addition, Yang’s group have employed the photoisomerization of azobenzene to modulate the activity of a DNAzyme.[69] They demonstrated that the activity of the DNAzyme could be reversibly switched ON and OFF using UV and visible lights. In the design, the DNAzyme was composed of two parts: the functional part and the regulatory part. The regulatory DNAzyme would form a hairpin structure to prevent the approaching of the substrate strand. When the DNA nano scissor was exposed to visible light, the azobenzene was stabi lized in trans form while the hairpin structure could form in the regulatory part, preventing the binding of the functional part to the substrate. Thus, the activity of the DNAzyme was inhibited. When the nanoscissor was irradiated by UV light, the azobenzene would take the cis form while the hairpin structure would dissociate to form an open strand, restoring the activity of the DNAzyme. One of the promising examples for photoresponisve 3D DNA nanostructures was developed by Tan’s group. They built a DNA tetrahedron that could contract and extend upon irradiation by UV (300 nm < λ < 400 nm) and visible light (λ > 400 nm) (Figure 6A).[70] In Sugiyama’s group, they employed the azobenzene moiety to control the association and dissociation of the DNA origami oligomers (Figure 6B).[71] The hexagonal DNA origami frames were functionalized with linker strands consisting of azobenzene. When the visible irradiation was applied, the planar trans form of the azobenzne would allow the two complementary strands from two different hexagonal frames to bind and link two frames together. When the UV irradiation was applied, the distorted cis form of azobenzene would disrupt the DNA duplex, resulting in the dissociation of the linked hexagonal oligomers back to monomers. Since the hexagonal origami frames were functionalized at different edges, the oligomers would take a linear or ‘V’ shape accordingly. They also showed the singlemolecule visualization of the hybridization and dissociation of oligonucleotides with photoresponsive moieties.[72] They
small 2017, 1602881
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(11 of 16) 1602881© 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com
constructed a DNA origami based frame with an inner cavity. Four DNA strands were coupled in the cavity in the manner that they could form two parallel double strands. The overhangs from the parallel parts were complementary to each other and incorporated with azobenzene moieties. When the azobenzene was in the trans form, the overhangs would bind to each other and form double strands. This would give an ‘X’ shape inside the cavity of the frame. When the UV irradiation was applied, the azobenzene took the non-planar cis form, while the duplex would dissociate and the two strands would revert back to the parallel state (Figure 6C). The process was fully reversible. Subsequently, the same group also used the azobenzene moiety to control the closing and opening of a square bipyramidal DNA nanocapsule.[73] The nanocapsule consisted of two halves. The two halves were connected with one edge strongly hybridized and the remaining three edges with tunable hybridization. The three edges were linked by complementary double strands and they were incorporated with azobenzene moiety. When UV light was irradiated, the cis-form azobenzene disrupted the duplex and dissociated and the two halves opened, releasing the encapsulated cargos (Figure 6D). When visible light was applied, the azobenzene took trans form and the two linking strands bound together and the two halves connected to form a closed nanocapsule. These opening and closing cycles were confirmed by gel electrophoresis.
Famulok’s group has designed and constructed a pseudorotaxane with two spherical stoppers at the two ends of one DNA duplex.[75] The macrocycle ring would rotate freely at first because the arm was capped by a complementary DNA strand that was incorporated with azobenzene moities. When azobenzene was in trans form, the strand could bind to the arm to form a duplex. When the UV light was applied, the azobenzene would take a cis form and the strand would detach from the arm, leaving the macrocycle ring free to bind to the arm (Figure 6E). The whole process was reversibly mediated by alternating irradiation with UV and visible light.
The second type of photo-responsiveness of DNA nanostructures came from the synthetic molecules that could be cleaved by light irreversibly. One classical type of these molecules usually consisted of an ortho-nitrobenzyl core. Light would cleave the structure at the site of benzyl carbon. In Willner’s group, they employed the ortho-nitorbenzyl phosphate to fabricate the photocleavable microcapsules.[76] The payloads were encapsulated by co-precipitation with CaCO3 particles and were covered by six layers of nitrobenzyl incorporated DNA strands followed by the dissolution of the CaCO3 core via EDTA etching. Those layers were cross-linked by nitrobenzyl-contained strands to prevent the natural leakage of payloads from microcapsules. The illumination of UV cleaved those DNA layers and then the trapped payloads were released in a controlled manner. Han’s group also used ortho-nitrobenzyl group to demonstrate the large-scale structural configuration of preformed DNA origami structures.[77] They assembled a hollow origami sphere that was composed of two hemi-spheres tethered by nitrobenzyl incorporated DNA strands at one side. At the opposite side the two hemi-spheres were permanently connected by regular DNA strands. When the UV
irradiation was applied, the cis azobenzene would destabilize the double-stranded linker and separate them into single strands. The two hemi-spheres would then be separated but linked by only one DNA strand linker. This structural change could be directly observed by high resolution TEM. Recently, Heemstra’s group used the ortho-nitrobenzyl group as the covalent self-caging moiety and showed the temporal control of the activity of the structure-switching aptamer.[78] They connected the complementary strand for the L-tyrosinamide aptamer with the nitrobenzyl group. The aptamer would bind to the complementary DNA strand due to intramolecular association and the aptamer function was temporarily suppressed. When UV light was applied to the system, the nitrobenzyl group would be cleaved and separated the complementary strand from the formed double strands. This would shift the equilibrium of the aptamer to the direction of binding of the target. Thus through the incorporation of nitrobenzyl group into the strand, they demonstrated the temporal control of the aptamer activity.
Recently, we constructed a simple ‘OR’ gate using light as the input.[74] The logic gate was built on a triangularshaped DNA template and the complementary strands were functionalized with different motifs such as photocleavable molecules, fluorophores and/or quenchers. Due to the close proximity of fluorophores and quenchers, the fluorescence was initially suppressed. When UV irradiation or two-photon excitation was applied, the photolabile linkers would be cleaved, the fluorophores would be separated from the quenchers, and the fluorescence would be restored. We showed that this logic gate could be repeatedly operated by adding the corresponding photocleavable DNA strands in the system (Figure 6F). This is the first demonstration of the use of light of different wavelengths as the inputs to perform the logic gate operations.

sections.heading: 3.1. Sensing and Detection
sections.text:
Krishnan’s group designed an I-switch based on cytosine-rich i-tetraplex structures for reporting the pH changes along various intracellular events.[79] They found that this DNA switch was stable in acidic endosomes at least for 2 h. After entering the endosomes, it could track the endosome maturation process with the FRET signal changes. When the DNA switch was coupled with transferrin, it could track the anionic ligand binding receptor pathway and report the endosome maturation progressively. The same group also designed a DNA nanomachine that could map the pH changes along two endocytic pathways including furin retrograde endocytosis and transferrin receptor endocytosis after cellular uptake (Figure 7A).
Several groups have used the stabilized G-quadruplex motif integrated onto the self-assembled DNA nanostructures for detection of zinc protoporphyrin IX,[83] iridium complex[84] and K+ ions in extracellular milieu.[85] Diao and his co-workers designed a three way junction DNA structure for the detection of Hg2+ ions and thiols in biological samples.[86] The working principle is the addition
small 2017, 1602881
www.advancedsciencenews.com
reviews
1602881 (12 of 16) www.small-journal.com © 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
of thiols such as cysteine or glutathione could extract the Hg2+ from the global structure, reverting it to the three way junction and restoring the fluorescence signals. This system could be used for the simultaneous detection of Hg2+ and thiols.
Recently, we have successfully developed a versatile recognition platform based ontriangular-shaped DNA nanotubes.[87] In this design, three different aptamer sequences were integrated as some of the building blocks along the three edges of the tube. We demonstrated that this DNA nanotube has shown its capability of selective discrimination and recognition of three different target molecules, giving rise to three distinguishable fluorescence signals. This DNA platform would allow multiple binding activities to be combined into a single system. In principle, it is feasible to generate libraries of diverse geometries that allow more binding events to happen at a time.

sections.heading: 3.2. Drug Delivery
sections.text:
Lo et al. designed a DNA nanotube with longitudinal variations by alternating small and large capsules.[80] By choosing the appropriate size of the gold nanoparticles that matches the size of the cavities, they found that cargo could be selectively trapped inside the nanotubes at particular positions. When the eraser DNA strands were added to the system, they hybridized to one of the closing strands along the nanotube via strand displacement approach. This would lead to the nanotube to become partially single-stranded and the trapped cargoes would be released from the nanotubes (Figure 7B).
Bermudez’s group built a DNA tetrahedron which was incorporated with a small fragment of antisense DNA.[88] Compared with antisense DNA itself, this complex structure was effectively taken up by cells while the antisense oligonucleotides could induce the degradation of corresponding mRNA. This resulted in a remarkable gene knockdown effect in cancer cells.
A pH-sensitive nanocarrier for the targeted delivery of anticancer drugs into tumor cells has been constructed by Gu and his co-workers.[89] This carrier consisted of two parts. One is the nanoclew, which was in rich in GC pairs. The
second part is the single-protein based nanocapsule, which was cross-linked by a pH-sensitive linker. They showed that the DNase I and anticancer drugs were successfully encapsulated in nanoscapsule and nanoclew respectively. Both nanoclew and nanocapsule were complexed to be a single carrier by electrostatic interaction. Once they were taken up by the tumor cells and reached the endosomes where the pH is much lower, the linkers were cleaved to open the nanoscapsule. DNase I was then released to further degrade the nanoclew for simultaneous release of anticancer drugs.
Willner’s[90] and Han’s groups[91] also employed the photolabile ortho-nitrobenzyl motifs as a linker to construct a photocleavabe DNA nanocontainers for the light-controlled release of molecular loads. When these nanostructures were irradiated with UV, the linker would be cleaved and the covalent attached/trapped payload would be released in a controlled manner. Different payloads such as from small molecules to large proteins have been tested using this delivery platform systemically and their biological activities have not be inhibited.

sections.heading: 3.3. Diagnosis and Therapy
sections.text:
Wang’s group used a DNA tetrahedron-based molecular beacon as a platform for the detection of tumor-related mRNA in living cells.[81] The molecular beacon was incorporated into one of the edges of the DNA tetrahedron and was designed to be complementary to the target mRNA sequences. When the mRNA target was present, it would bind to the loop and half of the stem. This resulted in changing the conformation of tetrahedron from a contracted state to an extended state (Figure 7C). This structural change could be monitored by fluorescence quenching effects.
Liang and his co-workers constructed a DNA origami that was loaded with the intercalated photosensitizer BMEPE for the efficient killing of tumor cells by photodynamic therapy.[92] They found that DNA origami structures would facilitate the cellular uptake of BMEPC. The photoactivation of BMEPC would generate destructive reactive oxygen species that could kill target cells efficiently. Due to the fact that BMEPC could also be activated by two photon excitation, it held great promise for clinical application. Recently, Weizmann’s
small 2017, 1602881
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(13 of 16) 1602881© 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com
group demonstrated the use of periodic DNA nano ribbons as the carrier for the efficient delivery of siRNA for gene silencing.[93] They employed the rolling circle amplification method to generate the scaffold strand and staple strands at the same time and assembled the DNA nano ribbon in a one-pot manner. The siRNA for suvivin was coupled into one of the staple strands and loaded onto the nanoribbon. After entering the tumor cells, siRNA induced down-regulation of corresponding gene and suppression of the transcription of mRNA. This study represented one of the facile methods for the large scale production of DNA carriers.
Liu and his co-workers recently constructed a label-free DNA-tetrahedron structure for early diagnosis of cancer in terms of detection of the telomerase activity.[94] The DNA tetrahedron was coupled with telomerase primer on the top vertex while the telomerase would elongate the TTAGGG sequence with different activities. After the deposition of polyaniline onto the whole structure and the formation of the G-quadruplex in the presence of K+ ions together with hemin ligands, the system could be used to detect the activity of telomerase using an electrochemical approach. The ultrasensitivity of the system provided a platform for the early diagnosis of telomerase activity from cancer patients.
Douglas and co-workers have constructed a DNA-based nanorobot in the form of a hexagonal barrel.[95] The barrel consists of two domains that were permanently linked in the rear. It was designed to be locked by an aptamer-complement duplex in the front In addition, the inner wall of the barrel was functionalized with antibodies that recognized specific surface receptors of certain cell types. When the antigen targets were present, the aptamer would bind to its target, resulting in the formation of aptamer-ligand complex and the dissociation of the linker duplex. This would further open the barrel and expose the inner wall to the environment. The binding of antibodies to the correct receptors on specific cell types would generate a readable fluorescence signal. Their nanorobot could potentially be used as competent carriers for molecular payloads to perform specific biological tasks such as diagnosis and delivery.

sections.heading: 3.4. Logic Gates
sections.text:
Kolpashchikov and co-workers have designed and constructed a five-input logic gate using a splitting strategy based on a two-input logic gate.[96] An RNA-cleaving DNAzyme was split into two parts and the catalytic region was blocked by two stem loop structures. Only with the simultaneous addition of 5 DNA strands as inputs could the two parts be connected, the blocked regions were unblocked and the active DNAzyme could form, then the substrate would be cleaved by the DNAzyme. Since the substrate has been functionalized with a fluorophore/quencher pair at its two ends, the separation of the quencher from the fluorophore could restore the suppressed fluorescence emission, which could be used as the output signal. By careful design, this 5-input logic gate could be used to detect multiple miRNA targets, including miR10b, miR-122, miR-21, miR-200b, miR-99a, which held great promise for disease diagnosis.
Wang also constructed a logic gate based on a molecular aptamer beacon (MAB), which could transform small molecules into outputs.[97] The molecular aptamer beacon contained the ATP aptamer sequence in the loop region. When ATP was used as the input, the formation of ligandaptamer complex would disrupt the MAB and expose the toehold region for a strand displacement reaction. The displaced strand would associate with two other G-rich strands to form a stable G-quadruplex that could be intercalated by protoporphyrin IX (PPIX) and give out a strong fluorescence emission. In this manner, an input of small molecule ATP was transformed into a readable output signal.
Wang designed a three-input majority logic gate that had the one-veto function.[82] The logic gate was constructed based on a split G-quadruplex. Hemin could intercalate into this G-quadruplex to form a DNAzyme. The logic gate consisted of two G-tracts while the three input DNA strands contained one G-tract respectively. At least two input DNA strands were added and the active G-quadruplex based DNAzyme could form and catalyze the oxidation of 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) into highly yellow color. Cu2+ ions could unfold the G-quadruplex permanently. When Cu2+ ions were added, the G-quadruplex could be deformed and the catalytic ability would be suppressed. Thus when Cu2+ ions were used as one input, it could veto the decisions made by other inputs with higher priority.
Zhang and co-workers have also employed the i-motif structures to construct NOR and NAND logic gates.[98] The formation of i-motif structures needed to be facilitated in an acidic environment. Thus, they exploited enzymatic reactions to generate the required acidic environment. The acetylcholinesterase could catalyze the hydrolysis of actylcholine into acetic acid while glucose oxidase could catalyze the oxidation of glucose into gluconic acid. The i-motif structure was modified with a fluorophore and a quencher at two ends and the fluorescence emission of the donor was used as the output. Thus, the ‘NOR’ gate could be built using the two enzymes as the inputs since the presence of either enzyme would generate an acidic environment and promote the formation of i-motif structures, which would bring the fluorophore and quencher closer, resulting in the quenching of the fluorophore. The enzyme invertase could catalyze the hydrolysis of sucrose into glucose. Thus, invertase and glucose oxidase could be used as inputs to construct a ‘NAND’ gate (Figure 7D).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions and Outlook
sections.text:
Stimuli-responsive DNA-based materials represent a major class of remarkable functional nanomaterials for nanobiotechnological applications. Different external stimuli, such as pH, metal ions, oligonucleotides, enzymes, small molecules, heat, and light were used to drive the switching/ structural changes of DNA nanostructures. The working principles of the DNA nanoassemblies in solution or in cellular environment were also demonstrated. Substantial in vitro studies have clearly revealed the advantages of the use of stimuli-responsive DNA nanomaterials in biomedical areas,
small 2017, 1602881
www.advancedsciencenews.com
reviews
1602881 (14 of 16) www.small-journal.com © 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
particularly for biosensing, drug delivery, therapy and diagnostic purposes in addition to bio-computing.
While significant progress and scientific advances in the development of stimuli-responsive DNA nanomaterials and their potential biomedical applications were accomplished, several important challenges are still ahead of us. Firstly, the introduction of additional triggers, such as mechanical, electrical, and magnetic stimuli, can be highly desirable and broaden the feasible applications of these responsive materials. In addition, the advancement of additional readout signals that monitor the responsive system, such as magnetic resonance imaging, surface plasmon resonance (SPR), and chemiluminescence resonance energy transfer (CRET), could provide novel characterization tools for practical applications.
Secondly, designing dynamic DNA assemblies simultaneously sensitive to dual- and multi- stimuli is highly challenging but desirable because these multi-triggered responses can provide novel means for smart nanostructures development. It is expected that dual and multi-responsive DNA-based nanomaterials capable of targeting complex a pathological environment may hold great promise in fine tuning the drug release profile and augmenting the therapeutic efficacy, and should be aggressively pursued in the future. For example, Keyser’s group recently presented a new approach to create multi-responsive and reversible liposomes assembly through an anchored DNA oligonucleotide, which simultaneously responds to three external stimuli: light, Mg2+, and temperature.[99] This multi-responsive DNA oligonucleotide represents a distinctive example of building block in which multiple stimuli can be simultaneously introduced to adjust the reversible formation of DNA micelles/assemblies.
Thirdly, most of these reported responsive DNA-based systems are often proof-of concept studies. Self-assembled DNA systems tested in in vivo models or stepped into the preclinical stage remain elusive. Even though the study of Douglas demonstrated the potential use of DNA nanorobots for diagnostic and payload delivery to diseased cells,[95] there are still many challenges that impede their transition from the bench to the bedside and need to be fully addressed. Their immunogenicity effects have to be fully investigated and monitored. In addition, the choice of stimuli has to be biocompatible. For instance, among external stimuli, light irradiation is realized as an ideal non-contact and noninvasive stimulus that can activate the azobenzene-functionalized nanomaterials with flexible, facile, and spatiotemporal control. However, the major disadvantage of light treatments is that not all regions of the electromagnetic spectrum are appropriate for clinical purposes. It is wellknown that UV light always shows poor penetration to the skin, blood, and soft tissues due to its strong absorption and scattering effects. Besides the light wavelengths, laser power density is another considerable factor as a laser power density greater than 1 W cm−2 would be harmful to the human. Such a dilemma can be solved by introducing photo-responsive chemistry motifs that respond to a longer wavelength of light, like near-infrared (NIR), to the DNA nanomaterials. The merit of designing NIRresponsive DNA nanomaterials for clinical use is its long wavelength irradiation allowing for deeper tissue penetration and less photodamage to the cells. Recently, we have successfully developed NIR-regulated, shape-changing DNA nanotubes by
introducing a 4-nitro-4′-phenoxy-1,1′-biphenyl photocleavable molecule to the nanotube architecture that enables the conformational changes of the rigid DNA nanotube from linear to bending features in response to 800 nm fs laser pulse inputs.[100] We have showed that these NIR-responsive DNA nanotubes were suitable being nanocarriers for drug delivery in cellular systems due to their excellent biocompatibility, low cytotoxicity, clean and controllable opening of the nanotubes. Indeed, while the two-photon uncaging action cross section of nitrobenzyl based photolabile groups remains lower than 0.1 GM,[101] the nitrophenetyl ones are much higher, over 10 GM, among the best described in the literature.[102] Such high efficiency will allow us to study the two-photon induced release of biologically relevant molecule easily, with classical lasers used in two-photon excited microscopy, avoiding the necessity to use a high intensity amplified pulsed laser.
Furthermore, none of research group has considered the use of functional DNA nanoassemblies in a brain system. The prerequisite of in vivo applications will be its biodistribution and biostability in living systems. It is well-known that the size, structure and dosage of DNA nanomaterials will have a great impact on their circulation and degradation time. In addition, the immune system may realize the DNA nanostructures as foreign nucleic acids, and two possible situations may happen; (1) the immune system clears them out to protect their own DNA and (2) the foreign DNA may activate the other individual’s genome, which leads to potential biosafety risks. Therefore, the structure-property studies and systematic toxicity evaluations are highly necessary. With the development of biological mimicry, it is anticipated that ‘camouflaged’ DNA nanostructures can be used to mimic intrinsic substances in order to escape from the immune system. More importantly, functional DNA nanomaterials capable of penetrating across the blood-brain barrier (BBB) are highly significant. More efforts should be paid to designing stimuli-responsive DNA nanoassemblies that can consecutively overcome this barrier and function well in the complex neurological system. For instance, coating the nanostructure with some functional moieties such as tetanus toxin C fragment (TTC),[103] polysorbate 80 (PS80),[104] and TGN peptide consisted of 12-amino acids[105] may enhance DNA assemblies transport across the BBB via receptor-mediated pathways towards the brain.

metadata.abstractText: Stimuli-responsive DNA-based materials represent a major class of remarkable functional nanomaterials for nano-biotechnological applications. In this review, recent progress in the development of stimuli-responsive systems based on self-assembled DNA nanostructures is introduced and classified. Representative examples are presented in terms of their design, working principles and mechanisms to trigger the response of the stimuliresponsive DNA system upon expose to a large variety of stimuli including pH, metal ions, oligonucleotides, small molecules, enzymes, heat, and light. Substantial in vitro studies have clearly revealed the advantages of the use of stimuli-responsive DNA nanomaterials in different biomedical applications, particularly for biosensing, drug delivery, therapy and diagnostic purposes in addition to bio-computing. Some of the challenges faced and suggestions for further development are also highlighted.
